Expectation1: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation1: A customer brings a child’s wooden toy that is broken, and the carpenter should provide a repair quote
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story:
I was sanding down the edge of a window frame when Mrs. Lee walked into my workshop, her eyes worried and hopeful. She held out a small, splintered wooden train—her son’s favorite toy, she explained, and asked if I could fix it. I could see the damage was more than superficial; it would take time to repair it properly. She needed a quote before the end of the day, and I could tell how much it meant to her.

But I glanced at the clock. My volunteer shift at the community kitchen started in twenty minutes. I was expected to be there on time, to set an example for the newer volunteers. Still, I knew the others could handle the first part without me if I was a little late. My hands hovered over the toy, my mind racing between the responsibility to my customer and my commitment to the kitchen. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
